Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy two cows to start a new breeding business.

loans.name: Chann

texts.en: Mr. Chann P. is a villager in Preaek Ta Nob village in Takeo province.  He is a laborer in a rice mill factory. His wife, Mrs. Oret Ve, is a laborer in a rice field. Although they try to work hard, they still don't earn enough income to support their family. Thus, Mr. Chann P. decided to ask for a loan to buy some piglets to start a new breeding business. He is the father of four children who are enrolled in local public school. His wife is shown with him on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy piglets

loans.name: Va

texts.en: Va S., 48, is a widow and lives with her two children in Dangkao, Cambodia. S. is involved in the business of sewing clothes, purses, and wallets. She is able to earn an income of USD $10 per day to help cover the family expenses. She has been engaged in this business since 2003. S. and her family members try to work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for the family. They are seeking to improve their business as well. As a result, S. is requesting a loan of US $1000 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. She wants to use the loan to buy a new sewing machine to expand her current business. This is her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy some cows to re-sell

loans.name: Sarth

texts.en:
Sarth C. is 31 years old and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She sells vegetables at the Phnom Penh market and is able to make about US$5 of profit a day. Her husband is a wedding chef and makes US$5 per day. This couple has six children of whom four are are in school and two are too young to attend.

Sarth C. is asking for a loan of US$1,000. She needs to purchase a motorbike to transport vegetables to sell at the market. She is shown with her husband in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport her vegetables

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy some cows for her husband to sell

loans.name: Ke

texts.en:
Ke R., 40, is married and lives with her five children in Dangkao, Cambodia. R. is involved in the business of preparing fabrics for sale at home and she is able to earn an income of US$2 per day to help cover the family expenses. She has been engaged in this business since 2009. Her husband is a professional chef for wedding parties. He always has to travel everywhere to earn money, and he is able to earn an income of US$2 per day.

R. and her family members try to work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for the family. They are seeking to improve their businesses as well. As a result, R. is requesting a loan of US$500 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. She wants to use the loan to buy wood to build a food shop where she will sell soup and porridge. This is her second loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy wood to build a food shop where she will sell soup and porridge

loans.name: Margie

texts.en: Margie C. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 27 years old, is widowed, and has two infant children. Margie owns and operates a business selling a variety of different products like shoes, dresses, shirts and more ready-to-wear items in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Margie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Margie is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Chroeb

texts.en: Mrs. Chroeb C. lives in Tuol Svay village in Takeo province. She is 41 years old. She is a farmer who owns two hectares of land to cultivate rice to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sophal, is the village president and a motorbike taxi driver. This family has a problem because their land has infertile soil, yet they did not have money to support their rice field. Thus, Mrs. Chroeb C. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to change the quality of rice field and increase the yield. She is a mother of four children. Two of the children are employees of a garment factory while the other two are enrolled in a local public school. Her husband is presented on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Barv

texts.en: Barv T. is 39 years old and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She makes and sells banana cakes at the local market to earn a living. She makes about US $5 profit every day. Her husband is a cow dealer. He eventually earns US $6 a day. This couple has four children, two of whom are in school. Barv T. is asking for a loan of US $1,000 for her husband to purchase cows to resell.

loans.use: To purchase cows to resell.

loans.name: Vutha

texts.en:
Mr. Vutha C., age 29, and his wife, Mrs. Sothea Ret, age 25, have been married since 2005 and have a young son. They are living with their parents approximately 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Vutha and his wife have been selling fruit (mango) since they were married. They buy it from their villagers and transport it to sell in Phnom Penh market. The couple hopes to expand their business to become bigger and bigger, so Vutha is applying for his first loan of $1,000 to purchase mango under contract for resale.

loans.use: To purchase fruits (mango) under contract for resale.

loans.name: Hector

texts.en: Hector N. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. He is 51 years old, is widowed, and has one school-aged child. Hector owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Hector joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Hector is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding his business. This loan will be his 3rd from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding his business

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene supports her family with a hog and duck-raising business. She's from Norala, South Cotabato. She is 37 years old and has two children, her eldest being 12 years old. She is thankful for her business because it sustains the finances of her family.

Arlene is now requesting a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. This will be very helpful in providing feeds and supplies necessary for her businesses.

loans.use: To buy feeds and supplies

loans.name: Savet

texts.en:
Mrs. Savet C., 45, and her husband, Mr. Bunthoeun Hul, 47, were married in 1990 and have four children: 3 sons are in school and 1 daughter weaves silk at home. The family is living on an Island of the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Savet is a silk-weaver, while her husband is a farmer. She obtained previous loans from Kiva through Maxima and is now requesting another loan of $600 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business. Also, she will use part of her loan to help provide capital for her husband in his farming business.

loans.use: To buy silk materials for her weaving business and to provide capital for her husband's farm

loans.name: Bernie

texts.en:
39-year-old Bernie manages a rice field and owns a sari-sari store in Norala, South Cotabato. He has three children and the eldest is 11 years old. He started his business in 1990.

in November 2008, Bernie joined CEVI. Now he’s requesting a loan of Php 12,000 to help finance his business. He will be able to purchase groceries for his store and supplies for his farm with this amount. The income he will receive is very helpful in continuing to send his children to school.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and groceries for his store

loans.name: Yaok

texts.en:
Yaok K., 29, is a widow who lives with two of her children in Takeo province. She is a professional tailor who works for US$5 a day.

Yaok K. typically spends around US$30 on food, US$5 on utilities and US$10 on other expense. To earn more money, she is asking for a loan of US$250 to purchase more fabric to make more clothes.

loans.use: To purchase more fabric

loans.name: Candelaria

texts.en:
Candelaria has a hog raising and rice farming business. She is 58 years old and lives in Norala, South Cotabato. She started her business in 1996. Her business helps a lot to provide for the needs of her family. She supports five children.

Candelaria is requesting a loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use it to buy farm inputs and feed for her pigs.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs and hog feed

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon, 39, is a rice farmer from Norala, South Cotabato. She manages a rice field and she also has a hog raising business. She has 2 sows and 23 piglets. She supports her family of three children (the eldest is 15 years old). She works hard in order to have a good harvest.

Corazon has limited capital – that’s why she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to apply for a loan. She’s requesting 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to support her business buying seeds and farm materials.

loans.use: To buy seeds and farm materials

loans.name: Flora

texts.en: Flora C. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin province. She is 38 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Flora owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling ready-to-wear items like pants, shorts and shirts in the local community. She is just starting this business. In 2009, Flora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily maintains a rice field in Norala, South Cotabato. She also manages a piggery.  She is 39 years old with six children to support. Her eldest is 21 years old. She strives hard so that she can send them school to finish their studies.

She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner, and asked for financial support for her business. She requested a loan of 15,000 Philippines pesos to purchase feed and fertilizers for the farm.

loans.use: Feed and fertilizers

loans.name: Hang

texts.en: Hang C., 28, is married and lives with two of her children in the Takeo province. She is a farmer who typically makes about $1 each day. Her husband is a construction foreman who makes $3 of profit a day. Hang C. is asking for a loan of $500, which her husband needs to purchase construction materials.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials

loans.name: Epifania

texts.en:
Fifty-year-old Epifania is living in Norala, South Cotabato. She has a hog-raising business and a rice-farming business. She started her businesses in 1982. She can have a good harvest, but sometimes fails due to pest attack. Her businesses really help in providing for the basic needs of her family.

Requesting a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., worth 12,000 Philippine pesos, she will be able to buy farm inputs and feed for the pigs.

loans.use: Farm inputs and feed

loans.name: Nov

texts.en:
Nov S., 26, is married and lives with her only child in Dangkao, Cambodia. S. is involved in a business of selling fabrics as a wholesaler and she is able to earn an income of $3 per day to help cover the family expenses. She has been engaged in this business since 2007. Her husband is a Cambodian traditional boxer and he is able to earn an income of $1 per day. 

S. and her family members try to work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for the family. They are seeking to improve their businesses as well. As a result, S. is requesting a loan of $200 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. She wants to use the expected loan to buy more fabric for resale. This is her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: Buy more fabrics for resale

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn's rice farming business is improving with the financial help offered by microfinance institutions. She has been a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc., an MFI, since 2008. She has been able to finance her business with the small interest charges.

Now Evelyn has requested a loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to continue to support her rice field and piggery. She is glad that her daily needs are met with the income she brings in.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn, 37 years old, has businesses in rice farming, hog raising and a sari-sari (general) store. Her business is located in Norala, South Cotabato. To help finance her businesses, she applied for a loan of 10,000 Philippines pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., since it provides the lowest interest rate as compared to her previous experience from others, which lessens her financing charge. This loan will enable her to buy groceries, feed and fertilizers.

loans.use: Groceries, feed and fertilizer

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma, 44 years old, is a rice grower and a piggery owner in Norala, South Cotabato, Minadanao. She has been helping her husband till their farm to be able to have an abundant harvest. Aside from rice, she is also raising pigs. The piggery and farm is what she hopes could provide her enough income to buy an adequate supply of food, clothes and other basic needs. 

She needs additional capital of 15,000 Philippine pesos to grow her business. The loan will help buy farming necessities as well as additional piglets and feed for her small piggery.

loans.use: Farm supplies and feed

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is a farmer from Norala, South Cotabato. She is 40 years old with a 14-year-old child. She has managed a rice field since 1991. It is the main source of income her family depends on.

Now she would like to request a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner, worth 12,000 Philippine pesos to expand her farm and supply the necessary materials for her rice field.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Jeanelyn

texts.en: Jeanelyn, 33 years old, is a rice farmer. She also raises pigs in her village. She has been able to earn income from her small farm and piggery which she uses to supply her family with food, clothing and other basic needs. She would like to apply for a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to fund her farm and buy farming necessities. The loan will also help a lot in buying additional piglets and feed.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and pigs

loans.name: Jerlyn

texts.en:
Jerlyn started her business in rice farming and hog raising way back in 2008. Today she is already 40 years old and lives in Norala, South Cotabato with two children. She owns a rice field and a piggery that sustain the needs of her family.

She would like to ask for a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. in the amount of 15,000 Philippine pesos. She will use the loan to buy materials for the farm and feed for her pigs.

loans.use: Farm supplies and feed for pigs

loans.name: Jover

texts.en: Jover, 36, manages a rice field in Norala, South Cotabato. He’s married and has four children. His eldest child is 12 years old. He needs additional capital to purchase farm supplies and fertilizer for his farm business. He’s requesting a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner, for 10,000 Philippine pesos. CEVI offers the lowest interest rate and the loan would be of great help in financing his existing business.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Consorcia

texts.en: Consorcia B. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin province. She is 50 years old. Consorcia is married and has seven grown children. To make a living, Consorcia sells lumber in the local community. Consorcia has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month through the business. In 2009, Consorcia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Consorcia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Consorcia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the third loan taken out by Consorcia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Judy

texts.en: Judy, 35 years old, has businesses in rice farming and hog raising located in Norala, South Cotabato. The eldest of her four children is 5 years old. The income she receives is enough to provide for the basic needs of her family. For her to help finance her business, she seeks a loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., since it provides the lowest interest rate.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Loida

texts.en: Loida, 45 years old, is a rice farmer. She owns a farm that she hopes could provide her family enough income to buy adequate food and clothing and fulfill other basic needs. She has six children. She wishes that some day she will be able to buy more farms to be able to support all her family needs. She is asking for a loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures Inc., a Kiva partner. She will use the loan to buy farming necessities to grow her harvest.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Marites

texts.en: Marites, 37, owns a piggery, a rice farm and a sari-sari (general) store. With these simple ways of living, she supports her 2-year-old child as well as her family. She needs additional capital to help grow her businesses. She requested a loan from Kiva's partner Community Economic Ventures, Inc., worth 12,000 Philippine pesos. She will use the amount to buy fertilizers, farm supplies and groceries for her store.

loans.use: Farm supplies and groceries

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en: Melanie, 44, is a farmer from Norala, South Cotabato. She tills a rice field as a source of living for her family. She’s the mother of four children. Her eldest is 16 years old.  She needs additional capital to finance her farm. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner, and requested a loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos. She will use the loan to purchase farm supplies and to improve her rice field.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Ninfa

texts.en: Rice farming is the main source of living for Ninfa, 55. She supports 12 children in her family. The income she receives from her rice field is just enough to provide their basic needs. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner, to take a loan with a low interest rate to finance her business.  She’s requesting 12,000 Philippine pesos to buy farm necessities and sustain her family.

loans.use: Farm inputs

loans.name: Rannie

texts.en: Rannie maintains a rice field in Norala, South Cotabato. He is 35 years old with a child to support. His farm is his main resource for making a living. He works hard so that he can fulfill his family's financial needs. He joined Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and asked for financial support for his business.  He has requested a loan of PHP 12,000 to purchase fertilizer and seeds for the farm.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca, 50 years old, is a rice farmer.  She owns a farm that she hopes will provide her family with enough income to buy adequate food, clothing and other basic needs.  She has eight children.  Her eldest is 31.  She wishes that someday she will be able to buy more farms to be able to support all of of her family's needs.  

She is asking for a loan of PHP 12,000 through Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures, Inc.  She will use the loan to buy farming necessities for growing her crops.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie, 32 years old, supports her family with her hog-raising business.  She owns a pig sty in Norala, South Cotabato.  She is thankful for her business because it fulfills her family's financial needs.

She is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures, Inc., of PHP 12,000.  This will be very helpful in providing feed for her pigs.

loans.use: To purchase feed for her hog-raising business

loans.name: Virgilio

texts.en:
Fifty-year-old farmer Virgilio plows a rice field. He strives hard, working on his farm to support his five children. He wants his children to have a bright future. He wants to improve his farming to have a greater income.

He heard about Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner that offers financial assistance to entrepreneurs like him. He joined and requested a loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos to support his farm.

loans.use: Farm inputs

loans.name: Wenifredo

texts.en: Wenifredo, 43, is a farmer with a poultry business in Norala, South Cotabato. He has three children to support. The income he receives from his business is quite enough to sustain his family. He is now requesting a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos from Kiva's partner Community Economic Ventures, Inc., to buy feed for his chickens and supplies for his farm.

loans.use: Feed and farm supplies

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma is 48 years old and in the rice-farming business in Norala, South Cotabato. She started her business back in 2005. She also raises ducks as another source of income. With the income she receives from her farm, the financial needs of her family are met.  

She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner, to take a loan for her farm. She requested the amount of 12,000 Philippine pesos as additional capital to finance her business. With this amount, she can buy fertilizers and feed for her ducks.

loans.use: Fertilizers and feed

loans.name: Lem

texts.en: Lem H., 30, is married and lives with her only child in Dangkao, Cambodia. H. is involved in a business preparing fabrics at home. She is able to earn an income of USD 1 per day to help cover the family expenses. She has been engaged in this business since 2005. Her husband is a construction worker. He is able to earn an income of USD 3 per day. H. and her family members work hard to try and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for the family. They are seeking to improve their businesses as well. As a result, H. is requesting a loan of US $200 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. She wants to use the anticipated loan to repair her house because the current house is very old. This is her third loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: House repair.

loans.name: Ke

texts.en: Ke S., 31, is married and lives with her five children in Dangkao, Cambodia. S. is involved in the business of preparing fabrics at home and also providing laundry services to people in her village. She is able to earn an income of USD 4 per day to help cover the family expenses. She has been engaged in this business since 2001. Her husband is a pipe worker. He is able to earn an income of USD 3 per day. S. and her family members work hard to help each other maintain a good standard of living for the family. They are seeking to improve their businesses as well. As a result, S. is requesting a loan of US $200 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. She wants to use the anticipated loan to repair her house. This is her third loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: House repair.

loans.name: Soam

texts.en: Soam N., 41, is married and lives with her four school-aged children in Dangkao, Cambodia. Songva is involved in the business of preparing fabrics at home. She is able to earn an income of USD 1 per day, which she uses to help cover the family’s expenses. She has been engaged in this business since 2003. Her husband is employed as a worker for a water supply company. He earns an income of USD 2 per day. N. and her family members work hard to help each other ensure a good standard of living for the family. They are seeking to improve their businesses as well. As a result, N. is requesting a loan of US $200 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. She wants to use the anticipated loan to purchase more fabrics to expand her current business. This is her third loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy fabrics to expand the business.

loans.name: Qahraman Group

texts.en:
Qahraman group is made up of five members that would like to complete the requirements of their businesses and to make their businesses grow. Altogether, they have requested a group loan of 50000 Afghani.

Zia Jan, the group leader, has a quilt sewing business. With the loan she receives, she would like to buy more good quality materials to attract more clients and to expand her business. 

Zholina, the second member, wants to take a loan for her tailoring business. She needs to buy an electric machine to add to the other one she already has. 

Shah Gul would like to receive the loan for her son. He has a general store. With the loan, he would purchase supplies that are not available in his shop, but are in much demand. 

Semin wants to take the loan for his brother, a mechanic. He would like to buy the necessary tools for his brother’s workshop. 

The last member, Nahid, would like to take the loan for her husband. He needs to repair his taxi to improve his work.

loans.use: To expand and progress their businesses.

loans.name: Nhha

texts.en: Nhha S., 23, is married and lives with her only child in Dangkao, Cambodia. Saren is involved in the business of preparing fabrics at home. She is able to earn an income of USD 2 per day to help cover the family’s expenses. She has been engaged in this business since 2005. Her husband is employed as a construction worker in the city, and he is able to earn an income of USD 2 per day. S. and her family members work hard and help each other to maintain a good standard of living for themselves. They are seeking to improve their businesses as well. As a result, S. is requesting a loan of US $200 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. She wants to use the anticipated loan to purchase more fabrics to expand her current business. This is her second loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy more fabrics to expand the business.

loans.name: Market Vendors Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
N. Sentongo is a hardworking and determined lady. She is a businesswoman who's been selling beverages and agricultural produce from Lugazi central market for over 15 years. She is grateful that her business has improved greatly over the years. N. is able to make 70,000/= weekly profit and this helps to take care of her expenses including paying school fees for her five children with the help of her husband. Her children are at the university and in secondary school. She also helps to take care of her siblings. 

N. needs a loan to buy more farm produce to sell including greens, tomatoes, cabbages, cassava, sweet potatoes and so on.

loans.use: To buy more farm produce for resale

loans.name: Namengo Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
Cosmas S. is the leader of his lending group in Lugazi. He is a married man and a carpenter in Kinyoro. He has operated his business for five years. He has two school-going children and he takes care of his siblings and parents. 

His biggest business challenge is having customers that delay payments after services have been rendered. However, he is grateful for the loans that increase his business capital, hence enabling him to carry on even in times of hardship. 

Cosmas makes chairs and desks and would like to introduce the making of very nice sofas in addition to the ones he currently makes. He needs a loan to be able to buy more timber and nails plus other necessities to make his job much easier.

loans.use: Buying more timber and nails plus other necessities to make his job much easier

loans.name: Kayanja Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
Catherine N. is a hardworking lady. She is married with three children, ages 7, 3 and 8 months, and she also takes care of other dependents. She is a tailor in the Kayanja trading center. She is able to make about 100,000 Ugandan shillings as profits every week from this business, which she has been doing for three years. 

Catherine is happy with her business. Although it is in a village setting, there is not too much competition and even if there were, she is so good at what she does. She gets orders from clients to make them clothes according to their demands and fashions and she is time conscious. She needs a loan to be able to buy more clothing materials, like the traditional wear, from which her customers can choose.

loans.use: Buying more clothing materials

loans.name: Lady Anne

texts.en: Lady Anne R. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 22 years old. Lady Anne is married and has an infant. To make a living, Lady Anne owns and operates a video-karaoke business. She owns a videoke machine and the customer will pay for a song they want to sing. Lady Anne has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Lady Anne joined HSPFI, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lady Anne has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Lady Anne is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the second loan taken out by Lady Anne from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Amarsumya

texts.en: Amarsumya is 34 years old and lives with his wife and four children in the Tosontsengel province in Western Mongolia. His wife is unemployed but she spends her time making dresses and buriad shoes (warm winter shoes) for her family members. Two of his four children attend secondary schools while the youngest two children stay at home with their mother. Amarsumya operates a water business with his horse-drawn cart. He buys drinking water at wholesale prices and sells it door-to-door in the ger (traditional Mongolian housing tents) districts for slightly higher prices. He began his business in 2005 and has been able to support his family since then, but would like to grow his business even more in the future. Amarsumya says, "I really love animals. My dream is to establish my own farm and raise livestock.” He is requesting a loan of 160,000 tugrugs to buy more food/hay for his horse, which his water business depends on.

loans.use: To buy more food/hay for his horse

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en: Emelia G. is from the village of Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 32 years old. Emelia is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Emelia operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling different goods such as coffee, milk, canned goods and, primarily, rice. Emelia sells a variety of rice per kilo or per sack in the local community. Emelia has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Emelia joined HSPFI, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Emelia is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the third loan taken out by Emelia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en: Sabina, 50 years old, is involved in rice farming. She lives in a town in Agusan Del Sur. She is married and has an 18-year-old child. Currently, she owns a one-hectare rice field. She also tills two hectares, which were pawned to her. She joined CEVI in September 2009 to take advantage of its financial services. She said she likes its programs, especially the low interest rate that is offered. She is now requesting a loan of PHP8,000, which will be used for farm inputs like seeds, fertilizers and others.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Kigunga Twezimbe Group, Lugazi

texts.en: N. Betty is the leader of her lending group in Kigunga, Mukono. She is a widow with three children who go to school. She also takes care of two dependants, one of whom is an orphan. Betty is a business lady who has been involved in the sale of fruits and vegetables from Nakawa for eight years. She is able to make a profit of 40,000/= a week. She buys her stock from the farmers and sells to retailers. It’s due to her trustworthiness that she is successful. In the future, Betty needs to have a retail shop in addition to her current business to earn more income. She needs a loan to help with buying more supplies like tomatoes, onions, yellow bananas, and with paying for her children’s school fees.

loans.use: To buy more produce and pay school fees.

loans.name: Maricar

texts.en:
Maricar M. is from the village of Camiguin Province. She is 46 years old. Maricar is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Maricar owns & operates a business buying and selling fish around the village and nearby places with her husband who used to drive their motorized vehicle designed for fish vending. Maricar has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Maricar joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maricar has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Maricar is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Maricar from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Conny

texts.en:
Conny K. is a 33-year-old married mother of one son, Kevin Uhuru. She lives with her husband, Lennox, a businessman in Kilifi, a coastal town in Kenya. Conny runs a passenger service transport business in Kilifi and has been in the business for 11 years now. Apart from that, she also keeps dairy cattle as a secondary business and this enables her to earn more income from the sale of milk.

Conny joined KADET recently and is now borrowing her first loan. She plans to purchase a new dairy cow and to purchase some spare parts for her passenger service vehicle. Her matatu (van) plies the Malindi-Kilifi route and has been doing well.

In the future, she hopes to send her son to a better school and diversify her business further.

loans.use: To purchase a new dairy cow and spare parts for her matatu.

loans.name: Zawadi

texts.en:
Zawadi M. is a 31-year-old married mother of two children. She lives in Kilifi, in the Coast province of Kenya. Zawadi is a business lady and has been selling clothes, shoes and Kangas (African printed materials) in the busy Biashara Street in Kilifi. She has been in this business for seven years.

Zawadi has been in KADET for a long time. She has been able to borrow and pay back two loans very well. This will now be her third loan. With the money, she plans to purchase men’s wear, shoes and an assortment of Kangas. Her customers are the locals as well as the visitors who frequent the area.

She hopes to rent another store and expand her business by purchasing more stock.

loans.use: To purchase men’s wear, shoes and an assortment of Khangas.

loans.name: Isabilito

texts.en:
Isabelito is a 44-year-old married man with four children. He is from Agusan Del Sur and like most of the people there, he is involved in rice farming. It is the only source of income for his family, so he works hard to ensure an abundant harvest. 

Lacking financially, he joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., to be able to support his business. He applied for a loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos. With this loan, Isabelito will be able to finance his farm. He can now buy quality seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs needed at his farm.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Victory Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
Joy K. is 45 years old and the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is married with five children between the ages of 14 and 24. Her first-born is at the University. She also takes care of one orphan. 

Joy has had a beauty salon in Butebe Village for eight years. Her biggest challenge is having debtors that do not pay on time for the services rendered. From her salon, Joy is able to make about 42,000 Ugandan shillings in weekly profits. These help her in taking care of her family and helping to pay her children’s school fees. She says that her good customer-care skills help her in winning and retaining her customers, hence more expansion. 

She hopes to expand her salon further and also wishes for prosperity for her family. Joy needs a loan to be able to buy more salon equipment for expansion.

loans.use: Joy needs a loan to be able to buy more salon equipment for expansion.

loans.name: Farida Sosun Group

texts.en:
This is the Farida Sosun group, which is made up of three female members. Qadria, who is a good tailor, is the group leader. Her purpose for taking a loan is to buy essential materials for her business to support her work in a better way and help her reach to the top of success. 

The second member is Sosun. She would like to take the loan for her husband, who has a stationery shop. With the loan, he will purchase more materials for his shop.

The last member is Shiama. She wants to take a loan for her husband to complete the necessities for his retail shop. 

They have requested a group loan of 42000 Afghani.

loans.use: To grow their businesses

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is a rice farmer. She currently owns a two-hectare rice field. At 35, she is married and has three children. Her oldest child is only 13 years of age. She works hard to be able to send them to school and to proviD. for her family’s needs. She hopes to grow her business someday. 

She asked for a loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos from CEVI, a Kiva partner, to help her business financially. The income she gets from the farm is really helpful to her whole family. With the loan she applied for, she will be able to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Ejerose

texts.en:
At 22, Ejerose is already married and has two children. Her oldest child is now 3 years old. Involved in rice farming, she currently owns a 1-hectare rice field, which she hopes to expand. When free of farming duties, she cooks viands (meals) and sells them around her neighborhood. This serves as immediate source of income for her family’s daily needs.

A member of CEVI, a Kiva partner, Ejerose is applying for a loan of 7,000 Philippine pesos. She will use this loan to fund her rice farm. She will buy farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn, 46,  is a married woman with a 7-year-old child. She lives on rice farming, just like her parents. She first learned farming from them. Now that she has her own family, she keeps herself strong and healthy to be able to complete the hard work required at the farm. 

She wants to double her harvest. To achieve her goal, she applied for a loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos from CEVI, to help her finance her farm. With this loan, Evelyn will be able to buy farm supplies like seeds, fertilizers and other items.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Huyagbat

texts.en:
Huyagbat B. is 37 years old and lives with his wife and three children in the Arkhangai province of central Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His two oldest children, 16 and 12, both attend a local high school, while the youngest one, 4, stays at home with his wife. 

Huyagbat operates a retail goods business in a stall at a local market. He usually sells small household items such as spoons, forks, scotch and brushes. He began with a working capital of 50,000 tugrugs, but with a lot of hard work, his working capital currently exceeds 400,000 tugrugs. He hopes to keep growing his business in the years to come in order to provide for his family and in order to send his children to university. 

Huyagbat is requesting a 400,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase goods that he can sell in his stall.

loans.use: To purchase consumer goods

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en: Luzviminda B. is from the village of Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 35 years old. Luzviminda is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Luzviminda makes and sells calendars for local businesses. Luzviminda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Luzviminda joined HSPFI, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luzviminda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Luzviminda is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the third loan taken out by Luzviminda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is 23 years old married. He graduated from primary school. 

Five years ago, he worked with his uncle and gained a lot of experience in this business. Then he decided to build a spare parts shop for himself so he could earn a reasonable income. He opened his shop and was able to attract many clients. 

With this loan, he wants to buy spare parts and materials to expand his shop and compete in the market.

loans.use: To buy spare parts and materials

loans.name: Baasantseveen

texts.en:
Baasantseveen is 32 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in a wooden house in the Tosontsengel province in the western part of Mongolia. His wife is housewife and takes care of the two boys, ages 4 and 1. 

After graduating from a university, Baasantseveen decided  to start his own business. In April 2008, he purchased tire-repair equipment with a loan from Xacbank and started his tire-repair business. The profits from his tire-repair business have allowed Baasantseveen to purchase planks for his yard, a refrigerator and carpets. Unfortunately, because he doesn't have a heated workspace, he has had to stop his tire-repair business during the winter months. During these months, he works for a local carpentry company. 

Even after such sporadic business operations, Baasantseveen has earned a good reputation among his customers for his excellent repair work. Because of  customers' high demand, Baasantseveen has decided to built a heated workshop so that he can stay open all year long to service his customers. He hopes to have a sustainable workspace and  large auto repair shop in the future. 

Baasantseveen says, “Even though I am young, I  am the head of a big family. I have to care for my two children, my wife, my mother and my three younger brothers. For me, it is nice to see their happy faces.”  

Baasantseveen is requesting a loan of  540,000 tugrug to buy logs and planks in order to build his indoor heated tire-repair shop.

loans.use: To buy logs and planks in order to build his indoor heated tire-repair shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more sorghum and maize for her business

loans.name: Munguntsetseg

texts.en:
Munguntsetseg is 41 years old  and lives with her husband and two children in the Arkhangai province in Mongolia. She and her family live in a “ger,” which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. 

Munguntsetseg started her mobile household goods retail business in 2001, with working capital of 1.000.000 tugrugs. To make a profit, she buys a variety of household goods for wholesale prices, drives across the province and sells them at a retail price. Her husband also operates his own business, but helps her if needed. 

As result of Munguntsetseg's hard work and good customer service, her working capital now exceeds 12 million tugrugs. She has purchased a larger Korean truck for her husband's transportation service. Munguntsetseg hopes to expand her business in the future. She is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrugs loan to purchase more household goods, which she can sell at a profit.

loans.use: To purchase  more household goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional clothes for her business.

loans.name: Luchie

texts.en:
Luchie E. is from the village of Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 22 years old. Luchie is single. To make a living, Luchie owns & operates a retail store where she sells ready to wear items like shirts, shoes, jeans, and more in the local community. Luchie has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Luchie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luchie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Luchie is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Luchie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy equipment for her business.

loans.name: Eltaf Group

texts.en:
The Eltaf group has three male members. These three members want to progress in their business and bring some changes to it.
They requested a group loan of 30.000 Afghani.
Zabiullah is the group leader. He has a shop where he sells clothes and cosmetics. With the loan he receives, he would like to purchase more good quality materials and clothes for his shop. 
The second member is Mirwais who has a tailoring business. With his loan, he will buy a sewing machine and other required materials for his shop.
The last member is Farhed who has a tire repair shop. He needs some tools for his shop, so with the loan he can solve his problem.
They would like to say that Kiva is an effective process that can support the entrepreneurs to start a business and sustain it as well.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for his shop

loans.name: Twesigangane Group, Lugazi

texts.en: N. Margaret is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is a hard-working and devoted lady who has had with a retail shop in Nantabulirirwa for a long time. Margaret is married with five children and she takes care of her siblings. Her business profits and savings help her in taking care of her family and dependants. In a week, Margaret makes 40,000/= profit and she hopes to increase this when she has more stock.  She needs a loan to be able to restock her shop with more sugar, salt, cooking oil, bread and soap for shop expansion.

loans.use: To buy more stock for her shop

loans.name: Dolgor

texts.en: L. Dolgor is 46 years old and lives with her husband and five children in a wooden house in the Arkhangai province of central Mongolia. Her two oldest children, 21 and 19, both attend college. The rest of the children attend a local high school. Dolgor and her husband run a dairy retail business in a rented stand in the local market. They began this business in 1998 and through the years, they have learned how to be successful in their field. When the business first started, their working capital was 40,000 tugrugs. However, after 12 years of hard work, their working capital has grown to 3,600,000 tugrugs. Because of the success of the business, Dolgor has been able to renovate her home and purchase an automobile to add to the comfort of her family. She says, "I couldn't find a job during the country's market transition, so we started this business. As a result, my family is living well and I'm satisfied." Dolgor is requesting a 3,500,000-tugrug loan to purchase different wholesale dairy products that she can sell for a profit at her stand.

loans.use: To purchase wholesale dairy products

loans.name: Pedrita

texts.en:
Pedrita C. is from the village of Sagay, Camiguin province. She is 55 years old, is separated from her spouse and has four adult children. To make a living, Pedrita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling different varieties of bananas to the local community. Pedrita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Pedrita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan Pedrita has taken out from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional commodities for her business

loans.name: Pheach

texts.en: S. currently weaves bamboo baskets for sale. She sells her finished product to buyers who come directly to her house. She makes many sets of baskets before selling out. She also orders baskets from other villagers and sells them to make additional income. Her husband helps her buy the raw materials and also raises ducks to produce eggs for extra profit. S. is taking out her loan to purchase more feed and ducks for her husband to breed. This couple was married many years ago and is blessed with seven children who go to school or to work.

loans.use: To purchase more feed and ducks.

loans.name: Margie

texts.en:
Margie C. is from the village of Clarin Misamis Occidental. She is 31 years old, is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Margie owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes  from selling pork barbecue and chicken barbecue in the market. Margie has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Margie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 24000 PHP from GDMPC. Margie is requesting a new loan of 24000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the sixth loan Margie has taken out from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth M. is a 44-year-old lady who is married to Joab Mwasamba and they are blessed with four children. She operates a grocery business in Kilifi town which she has been operating for the last nine years. Her business has been doing well all this time.

Elizabeth is borrowing her second loan from KADET and plans to use the money to purchase more groceries for her kiosk. She hopes to clear her repayments in time and to continue taking up more KADET loans. 

Her dream is to expand her business and to see her children successful in future.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries for her kiosk

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida J. is from the village of Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 41 years old, is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Nida owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Nida is just starting this business.

In 2009, Nida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan Nida has taken out from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This borrower is 33 years old and married, and he has one child. He owns a bakery. He has been working in his shop for three years and acquired a great deal of experience. He employs two waiters who work with him to keep the business running. He will use the loan to buy a pot for kneading dough and to enlarge his shop so that it attracts more customers, and earns him more income.

loans.use: To purchasing a kneading pot

loans.name: Munhbat

texts.en:
Munhbat is a 42-year-old single man who lives with his parents in Arhangai province, Mongolia. He and his parents live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Along with caring for his parents, Munhbat operates a wooden plank retail business. He purchases planks from Tsenher small administration center in Arhangai province and transports them to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, where he sells them for a profit.

Since he began his business, he has been quite successful with his working capital growing to 6 million tugrugs (~4095 USD). His success has allowed Munhbat to renovate his home and hence to better care for his aging parents. He is requesting a loan of 1,400,000 tugrugs (~ 975 USD) in order to purchase a large amount of wooden planks for his business.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of wooden planks

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional goods for her shop

loans.name: Tungalag

texts.en:
Tungalag is a 35-year-old businesswoman who lives in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia with her husband and 12-year-old daughter. Her husband is a worker at the municipal treatment authority and her daughter is a student at a local secondary school. Tungalag and her family live in a “ger”, a traditional Mongolian tent. With a goal to have savings for her daughter's future life, Tungalag started her second-hand goods retail business in 2003 with a working capital of 80,000 tugrug (~55 USD).

After gaining more selling and business experience, Tungalag decided to expand her business not long after it opened. Since 2007, she has traveled to China, where she buys new clothes and then sells them in her two rented stalls at the local trading center. Today, her working capital exceeds 1,250,000 tugrug (~855 USD). Now, Tungalag has a dream to expand her business and have her own workspace. She is requesting a loan of 800,000 tugrugs (~ 575 USD) to purchase more clothes.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for sale

loans.name: Rodgers

texts.en:
Rodgers M. is a married man aged 39 years and has three children aged 13, 9 and 1 year old. He lives in Kilifi where he operates a retail shop in a place called Ngerenya business centre. His business is four years old and is doing well.

Rodgers has been a KADET member and is now borrowing his second loan after successfully servicing his first loan of Kshs. 36,500. With the money, Rodgers plans to expand his business premises and to also add more stock into his retail shop.

His dream is to run a wholesale store in future and he is optimistic that this will be a reality.

loans.use: To expand his business premises and to add more stock into his retail shop

loans.name: Srey

texts.en: S., 38 years old, is a good mother blessed with four children. Her four grown children go to school or to work at different occupations. Her husband is a civil service officer who works in a national prison. S. earns a living as a domestic rice cultivator. Presently she owns a machine to provide her service. She is always hired by people to plow their farmland. Recently S. faced a problem with her farming; she lacks some supplies to perform her business. Thus she looks for a loan to purchase a machine and pump to irrigate her crop. She will buy more fertilizers if any money is left from the loan.

loans.use: To purchase a machine and pump.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more commodities for her business

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen N. is 31 years old and a business man in Kilifi town. He is single and has no children. Stephen has rented a stall where he sells a wide variety of clothes. His business has been there for the last seven years and it has been growing with time.

Stephen has been able to borrow and successfully repay two loans from KADET and is currently borrowing a third loan of 80,000 KES. He plans to purchase more stock of men’s wear and an assortment of Khangas (African printed materials) for the women.

Stephen hopes to expand his business by investing the profit he is making back into his business. He also hopes to open a new stall in the same market in Kilifi.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of men’s wear and an assortment of Khangas for the women.

loans.name: Ladie Claire

texts.en:
Ladie Claire S. is from the village of Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 24 years old. Ladie Claire is a widow and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Ladie Claire owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for her trade comes from a la cart business. She grills chicken parts like chicken feet, hot dogs and intestines, to sell in the local community. Ladie Claire is just starting this business.

In 2009, Ladie Claire joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Ladie Claire is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to further develop her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is 51 years old and married, and he has 3 children. He has a bachelor's degree and 15 years of experience in the food and restaurant business. He is the best chef. He has helped to train many people in this field who are now famous and are working in the 5-star hotels and restaurants.

He wants a loan to purchase a cooker and a freezer for his food production business.

loans.use: To purchase a cooker and freezer

loans.name: Alinyikira Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
N. Robinah is 46 years old and married with seven children between the ages of 7 and 25, and she also takes care of four siblings. 

Robinah has operated a poultry farm in Kasangalabi for three years where she keeps both broilers for meat and layers for eggs. The layers eventually are used for meat. 

This is the second time that Robinah has sought a loan from Pearl Microfinance. She is happy to say that the first loan helped her in expanding her farm. With this loan she will be able to buy more chicken feed for her farm and also a ledger for keeping track of her layers.

loans.use: To buy more chicken feed and a ledger for keeping track of her layers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her business.

loans.name: Leng

texts.en: Mrs. Leng S. is a vendor whose main activity is to sell cooking ingredients. She started in the grocery business in the beginning of 2000. She has a partner in her husband, who helps feed the family by working in construction. This couple is married and has been blessed with four children. One of the children is married and lives separately and others attend school. To help the family, one grown daughter works in a garment factory. Because mature rice has a low price this season, Leng S. wants a loan to use as capital, which will enable her to order rice in bulk to resell for additional income.

loans.use: To order rice in bulk.

texts.en:
Iris O. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 27 years old. Iris is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Iris owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Iris is just starting this business.

In 2009, Iris joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Iris is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to further develop her business.

loans.name: Ambrose

texts.en:
Ambrose K. is 32 years old and married to Marian. Ambrose runs a small scale lumber business in Kikambala in Coast Province. He purchases raw lumber, cuts it to size and then sells to the locals for construction. He has been doing this for four years now.

Ambrose joined KADET recently through his neighbor and is now accessing his first loan. He plans to purchase more raw lumber for processing. His main clients are area residents and his prices are quite fair. 

He hopes to develop his small scale business into a bigger and more profitable lumber store.

loans.use: To purchase raw lumber for processing.

Lilia has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately $100 a month for these activities.

This is the second time Cate has requested a loan from Pearl Microfinance, and she hopes this one will also work wonders for her. Cate hopes to expand her shop with more goods which she believes will help bring in more profits, hence more savings. 

She is grateful that she has been able to pay school fees for her children as well as taking good care of them.

loans.name: Melissa

texts.en:
Melissa M. is from the village of Lumapas Bonifacio Misamis Occ.. She is 27 years old. Melissa is married and has 1 infant-aged child. To make a living, Melissa owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling fish    in the local community. Melissa has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Melissa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melissa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. Melissa is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Melissa from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

loans.name: Baasandorj

texts.en: P. Baasandorj is 24 years old and lives with his wife and 2 year old daughter in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. He and his family live in a "ger", or a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife works in a service center in his town and P. recently began a transportation service. Using his truck, he transports firewood throughout his province. When he began his business, his working capital was 700,000 tugrugs but now has increased to 1,500,000 tugrugs. He hopes to keep growing his business so that he can provide for his growing family and see to his daughter's future education. He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (approx. $1,375 USD) loan in order to purchase a large amount of firewood which he can sell to people outside his town.

loans.use: to purchase a large supply of firewood to resell

Estrella plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị Thúy's Group

texts.en: H. Nguyễn Thị Thúy (10102080022) is a 37-year-old female living in the town of Đông Anh, Hà nội. She is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Phố Chợ (1). H. is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she operates a business providing food services to local community members. She has been engaged in this business for over eight years and earns approximately 2,500,000 VND a month. In 2004, H. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,300,000 VND from SEDA. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding her business. H. is now requesting a new loan of 6,758,000 VND which will again be used to invest in expanding her business. The loan will be her 6th from SEDA. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About the Other Borrowers in the Group: 1. Nguyễn Thị Bé (10102080020) is a 60-year-old female who is requesting a 6,322,000 VND loan to support her business running a food stall. 2. Phan Thị T. (10102080021) is a 49-year-old female who is requesting a 6,322,000 VND loan to support her business running a food stall. 3. Nguyễn Thị H. (10102080019) is a 50-year-old female who is requesting a 6,322,000 VND loan to support her business running a food stall. 4. Nguyễn Thị H. (10102080023) is a 33-year-old female who is requesting a 5,450,000 VND loan to support her business operating a specialized retail store. 5. Dương thị Thúy H. (10102080024) is a 41-year-old female who is requesting a 6,322,000 VND loan to support her manufacturing business. About SEDA: The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low-income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. ***************************************************** H. Nguyễn Thị Thúy (10102080022) là 37 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Đông Anh - Hà nội. H. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Phố Chợ (1). Trong khi không pH. chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ thực phẩm cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương. H. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 8 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, H. kiếm được khoảng 2,500,000 VND. Vào 2004, H. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. H. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 5,300,000 VND từ SEDA. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,758,000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 6th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. Nguyễn Thị Bé (10102080020) là 60 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6,322,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. 2. Phan Thị T. (10102080021) là 49 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6,322,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. 3. Nguyễn Thị H. (10102080019) là 50 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6,322,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm. 4. Nguyễn Thị H. (10102080023) là 33 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5,450,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng. 5. Dương thị Thúy H. (10102080024) là 41 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6,322,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh sản xuất. Về SEDA: Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung T. hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.
